video.title: What is a Daily Standup? - Dev Life
video.description:
The Daily Stand Up (aka DSU) is a part of the Agile Software development process (and SCRUM). These meetings are a short, helpful, and necessary part of the day for many developers.

A lot of new devs wonder what web developers do on a day-to-day basis. In this video, you will learn all about the Daily Stand Up meeting, which is common in many development jobs. You will also learn tips to help you through your first DSU. 

Video by Anissa Deanna.
🎥Anissa's YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVOKt2XgozvMSnZDZGMdetg
📷Anissa on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/anissadeanna/

topLevelComment.author: Black Clover
topLevelComment.text:
Doing the standup is the most ridiculous thing companies do! Why not have a regular meeting where everyone can do whatever they want sit or stand?! I absolutely hate it and avoid companies that do this.

Btw, thanks for the explanation Anissa, for the rest of the people who didn't know what an abomination of a company practice this is.

replies.author: Anissa Deanna
replies.text: Lol, I understand where you are coming from. For me it works. I'm on a team of 3-4 ppl including my ITPM and sometimes the 508 guy or someone from dev ops. It really just helps keep us on top of priority stuff. We don't talk to the business, so it allows us to hear if we are on the right track or get updates. Now a days, it usually last less than 10 minutes which is nice. With bigger groups it was a pain, at one point they combined a bunch of devs working on different apps into one DSU and it wasn't helpful and lasted closer 20minutes. I work from home, so a lot of the time I was working on my own stuff and just listening for keywords or my name in the DSU convo. I think its value depends on the situation and it's up to the ITPM to make sure it works for the team.

topLevelComment.author: Hunter Lee
topLevelComment.text: I appreciate being able to review my work every day. but I would be nervous about what part of of the job i wold be in the middle off. I tend to just go until the sun goes down, with intermittent breaks, so that i can get through as mch work in one day as possible, but at any specific time of day i could be at any point in my work. I would probably take notes of what i was doing as i was doing it, because what "blocker" i was having I then resolve. would that even be nessessary, or would it be approppriate to just say you have no blockers every day unless it's lasted, say, more than on day to resolve?

replies.author: Anissa Deanna
replies.text: I totally get where you are coming from. Most days, I usually don't have blockers. Today I said something like, "Yesterday, I worked on the issue where there was a silent fail during deploy, today I plan to pair-program with my teammate to fix said problem quickly so that we can deploy to production asap, and other than that, no blockers." I also added in some other things I planned todo after I fixed the issue. If you have no blockers for several days, great. If you have a blocker currently, say what it is but that you are "confident you will fix it in an hour or so".  Otherwise, when I'm truly stumped, I might say "I've been working on this task for a day or so and I'm a bit stumped, if someone wouldn't mind pairing up with me today or pointing to some resources, I would really appreciate it."
